Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 12:15PM - edited Sep 25, 2010 12:29PM by Annabella58 Sweetheart, you are right to look into this.  That said, an inverted nipple is something that you should actually see a breast surgeon about.  Don't worry, the chances of something being cancer at  your young age are extremely slim.  Also, they cannot really do a mammogram on you, as young breast are very dense. However, a breast surgeon is the person who can really lay your mind to rest.  Since you have pain, (sure, diet can do this, as in caffeine) you may have a fibroid or something that is benign but that should come out.  My sister did, at 19.  It wasn't any big deal, and she's never had a thing since, but if there is breast cancer in the family, or even if there isn't, get thee to a breast surgeon pronto.  (JIC, god forbid, there is something, you need to see one ASAP.) Since it does not show up on U/S, it sounds like a benign fluid filled cyst, but you are more than wise to check it out.  A benign cyst can wax and wane with your periods, but it won't show up on an ultrasound.  A fibroid will, so that lets that out.  Do you have any leaking from your nipple?  Are you on birth control pills?  There may be a hormonal imbalance also, that could cause these things. You don't mention your dr. as being a breast surgeon, but call your OB/GYN or your GP and ask for a referral.  If you post where you are, we can refer you to someone.  Then go, and continue being such a wonderful, pro active lady on behalf of your own health! You are the age of my own daughter and I am very proud of you for addressing this, but please know that your age will probably rule very much in your favor.  That said, it is not impossible, so for your own sake I would push you to do this. p.s. If you did see a breast surgeon, I would continue to push that doctor for further testing...you can and should have an MRI which isn't any big deal and should be covered by your insurance.  Insist on one.  Take care of you! love annie

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 06:30AM Annabella58 wrote: gee, you could be me...I had the almost exact same diagnosis.  Only thing is most likely your age.  You are young for this (my journey began at 46, I am now 55) and I had this twice.  First time, only DCIS, had rads and lumpectomy, tamoxifen for 5 years.  Was your cancer aggressive/HER2Neu+/ER+?  If any of those are there, it shifts the balance somewhat.  I was unable to do rads, due to prior rads on same breast, so I had no choice re: chemo. Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 12:28PM Annabella58 wrote: Hi Missy; i  fibroademonas for years, before bc came into the picture, they always said they looked suspicious etc.,,,but after biopsies, no cancer. Yes, they hurt like the devil.  The rule is this: If they hurt, move around freely, wax and wane with your cycle, prob. not cancer.  However!!! If a surgeon says "suspicious" etc., go and get the core biopsy.  There is no down side to getting one (except it hurts a bit, take some tylenol) and makes you nervous until you get results (take an antianxiety pill) but most of all, if it is cancer, you need to catch is super early!!!   That way you'll be just fine.  Either way, you'll be fine. Good luck to you!! Will send some prayers your way for a good benign result.  Sometimes they just do check one of them, if they all have the same characteristics, they can rule stuff out.  However, it sounds like they are being very good and thorough for all 3 to be biopsied. Take care Annie

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2007 06:30PM Annabella58 wrote: Hey there, am a two time bc lady, undergoing the second stuff right now...I'd get the biopsy, pronto.  It doesn't hurt, just novocaine and then it's pretty quick, the worst part is waiting on the results. I had calcifications that no one thought were anything, they did biopsy them (they show up white) as they can be or not.  They were!!! Thank god i went ahead with the biopsy.  This time, I had an MRI dictated by the fact that I already had cancer.  The mammo was perfect, so was an ultrasound.  But the MRI found a small invasive cancer that was totally hidden by everything else.  This includes many the blood test to check for cancer flags, and drs. visits, etc. I am so not trying to scare you, it's probably benign, but my point here is, it's just a biopsy, 20 minutes vs. what could be your life.  If you catch it early (and you'd be really early) it's the best of all possible worlds and minimal treatment.  Please please please, if I can pass on any good to you at all................get it biopsied!!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 08:15PM Annabella58 wrote: I am not at your stage, but no one should deal with this alone.  Please do not give up!!! I had no insurance at all when I had my first diagnosis and all the txtments, etc. came to a very high sum.  Hospitals MUST work with you, and this is how it works.  You have to ask.  They will not offer you financial deals, so if you can get your taxes together from last year, show them your monthly expenses and income, and ask for a "financial consult for a payment plan consideration" you can get an appt. with the finance dept. From there, you can work out a plan that you CAN afford, even if it is as little as 15.00/month.  If you evince willingness to work with them, and you go to them, you cannot be put into collection, legally.  Stay tough, insist on your figure that it is all you can do, but reiterate that you are willing to pay your bill, you just need to be able to do it in a way that you can afford. This will save your credit, your finances, and avoid collection.  Do not worry, this can be done, as I did it.  It is now 9 years since all that began, we are still paying it off (I got a plan of 100.00/month) but you can do it too. Your kids need you!!!!!!!!!!  You have many friends here.  Go onto the Stage IV threads and those wonderful ladies will steer you right and be your buddies. Best of luck to you.  Remember, your kids need you and they always will, so put on that fighting hat! xoxo

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 06:48PM Annabella58 wrote: hello dears: I just wanted to interject a note of ease here.  I took it, not for preventative, but for IDCIS.  I took it for 5 years, and honestly, it was fine.  You sure won't read about the ones of those that are fine; those that post are posting for support with it, generally. I also am queen of SEs...in fact, my onc calls me "sally side effect"...it's that bad.  If there is one, I'll get it. Well, I read up on it, and I was terrified of it.  However:...if you take ANY drug, you should be wary of those awful side effect circulars they give you.  You'd never even take a tylenol, if you read those!  Not to mention the terrifying SEs they list on commercials....we have all been scared by those.  Long story short.  I wanted the protection tamoxifen gives, which is very good.  Of course, I was scared of SEs, but I did not get any.  Nada.  In fact, I've never felt better in my life!  Now this could be due to eating better and exercising, but I don't know....I just felt and looked great.  I kept my period all thru it, I lost weight, I  had great hair, and I actually felt very safe each time I took that white pill.  Now, I do not know your risk factors, but it is worth noting that if you go ahead and take it, that you cannot take tamoxifen twice.  You'd have to go to an AI if you ever developed bc down the road.  It's definitely worth a long consult (scheduled as such, so he doesn't rush you out of it) with your oncologist about WHY he wants you to take this, and what the risk factors are if you do not.  Get statistics from him.  You should not take this without good reasoning behind it that makes sense to you. In the end it's a gut decision.   I suspect that if you wanted to begin a thread about someone NOT having SEs on an AI, that you'd get quite a few women weighing in, it's very true that those having no issues don't post alot. Good luck whatever you go with and PM me if I can help you further.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2012 02:13PM Annabella58 wrote: green shamrock, I am a fibroadenoma queen...don't even do self exams anymore, as they are a minefield.  My BS maps them, but I tend to keep popping them. What I learned from soooo many over the years (and no, the cancer wasn't palpable,did not hurt, and I never knew til an MRI found it), is that if it shrinks and grows during your cycle, (even if you are in menopause, the body still has a type of cycle) it is almost definitely a fibroadenoma. Didn't get them til my 40s, either.  See if caffeine makes it worse.  Is so, and the size changes, you have yourself a fibro.  They can stay still or move.  However is it also regular in size and smooth feeling?  Does it feel sharp and sharp edged?  All good indicators of what it is/is not. (regular, smooth, moves usually but not always usually fibro.  Sharp, fixed can be a cancer but at all all the time in any way)  as stated 80% are benign.  That is a huge percent and would give you a nice solid B grade in school. good luck to you, but please bring any and all lumps to a drs. attention.  Yes, this means I am in the Drs all the time.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 05:28PM Annabella58 wrote: Hi, I can understand your concerns, I was very early period (9) and still not in menopause at 53 when I had my ovaries out.  I had my daughter late (30) and she got her period at 11. She was 12 when I had cancer the first time.  Since the breasts are so very dense, I would not put your daughters thru a mammogram, as they cannot see anything nor do I believe any doctor would let you have a script for that.  I would wait and when they are older, encourage them to get mammograms when they feel the need to.  But I was told that no one, unless they have a mom  or a strong family cancer history (we did not, I am the first I know of), needs one until at least 30. Since I was 35, I am leaving it up to my daughter to get one when she feels she should.  If she wanted to start at 28 or so, well, that is her choice.  Earlier, if she wants to, and someone will give her a script. I certainly wouldn't subject your young girls to anything of the sort.  They are unable to test for BRAC gene until they are 25 anyway.  That's just my opinion, but good luck.  My hope is that in the next five or ten years, there will be a better answer for our daughters.  I know mine is already scared, and she is only 21. I would share with them that there are things they can do for now to keep them healthy.....when they develop breasts, they can self check them.  They can eat healthfully with lots of fruits and veggies.  They can omit alcohol.  They can not smoke.  They can stay away from the pill as contraception.  Hopefully these things can empower them to not worry so much.  My heart goes out to you, as mine was the same age....tell them mommy is a Viking warrior and that you are going to win, and that's that.  In your own head, tell it just to get the He** out, wrong girl, period. Good luck!!

If you had a normal mammogram a year ago, there is no reason to suspect that you would have anything going on.  While yes, things do happen, unless you have an abnormal mammo or they want you to have an MRI, then there is no reason to think this, other than fear of it? I think that for your own peace of mind your best course of action is the mammo.  Then, until then, to ease your mind, I think this may be related to your work, honestly and muscle spasms. Bodies are usually aching for reasons.  In your line of work there is a lot of sitting still.  You are at peri menopause age.  Lots of things begin to ache at this stage.  Peri menopause causes aches, pains and stabby boobs.  Also what side do you use or reach with?  Sounds like body mechanics to  me may be the culprit. If it were me, I'd go to my GP and rule out lyme disease, or even beginning arthritis.  You may just need some exercise.  Get a good CBC blood test and if everything seems normal, then go get that mammo and rule that out too. Unless you have a strong family history of breast cancer, or have had it before, there is no reason you should think it is stage 4!  Or even breast cancer.  Go see your GP and get your mammo and good luck.  I believe you will be just fine, hon.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 10:21AM Annabella58 wrote: Hi all, RaeinNZ, "garden variety" is what my oncologist called it.....certainly not my "flippant" comment.  And I agree.  Kira, yes, CMF is often called "chemo light" by the oncologists.  It's still chemo, and in no way "light" but it has a less toxic profile in terms of SEs.  Most women (on the "get me thru txmnt" thread, alot of CMF-ers) were able to lead their lives, keep their jobs, exercise, but needed a few days to regroup after the txtmnts.  I was node negative, some were node positive, your onc is the one to make the call about your treatment plan.  Originally mine wanted me to go with the ACT, but I told him, I wanted the one that lasted longer and was less toxic.  He thought it was perfectly reasonable in my case.  Typically, CMF last about 6 months as infusions are only once every three weeks.  It has a proven track record of being just as effective, altho again, this would depend on your particular scenario. My onc did the oncotype test without even asking me, as due to prior rads, I couldn't do rads again.  I got a 17, but had no other option than chemo. It was not fun, but it was, perfectly do able. Be well, all.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 03:36AM Annabella58 wrote: Hi Rose, I do and I did. Neither did I have any bc in the family and I took the precaution of it as even tho it was not in my nodes, I got it again. Yes, your body still makes estrogen from your adrenal glands.  Just a small amount. This will put you into surgical menopause if you have not done it(no biggie for me at all) and if you are past menopause it gave me great peace of mind. There is much discussion on whether it affects your bone density, risk of dementia, blah de blah, but I have no substantiated studies on these....according to every dr. I spoke with (some at Yale and some at Memorial Sloan in NYC) these are "perhaps" scenarios. I did this about 4 years ago and have never looked back.  In fact, due to my high estrogenic content, one dr. told me "you just saved your own life". Easy surgery, boring recovery.  Go for it, but research if first.  It's a very personal decision. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2011 11:11AM Annabella58 wrote: Hi there, Pauline! I am a two times bc lady, but your post caught my eye as I've had sooo many scares with this tupe of thing.  The bc did NOT hurt and was not felt at all either time. I have learned in all of this stuff (10 years worth) that if it: Is painful and shrinks and grows with your cycle Is smooth, oval or round and moves easily and is easily palpable they generally have found it to be a cyst; either fluid filled or what is called a fibroadenoma, a benign growth.  These lovely little items increase with age, esp. as we become pre menopausal.  It sounds like it should be just fine, but am saying a little prayer for you anyway.  I'm glad you are getting it checked out.  If they want to biopsy it, no worries, quick and just a needle and you're shot full of novocaine.  It truly does sound cyst=ey, but I know what a pain in the rear it is figuring out these things on weekend.  You'll feel alot better, once they U/S it and can see if that's all it is, and it sure sounds like it. As my hubby says: "If it is, it is, they'll fix it.  If not, hey, great!"....here's sending you the "not" vibe!  Most lumps are benign. Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2010 04:48AM Annabella58 wrote: I used "cured", as I don't want people to worry about me.  Felt kind of dumb when we had a 5 year "cured" party, and then I got it again the very next year.  People kept saying "but we just had your party!" (as tho it was my fault, or like the party was some kind of charm). That said, the mind is super powerful.  A bus could hit you tomorrow.  Life itself is a fatal disease.  Many women have horrible metastises and suddenly go into remission and live another 35 years (my aunt, pancreatic).  People with gorgeous cholesterol, perfect blood pressure and strong bones have heart attacks and die.  Here's the thing, after 5 years, even after 3 years, both times I have noticed that the "red flags" drop a bit.  They are still cautious up til the two year mark, but they do seem to quit overreacting so much.  I don't mind, I'm here due to an overreaction on the part of my oncologist for an MRI. Look at Lance Armstrong.  No one knows.  But after 5 years, go have the party!!  You cannot live looking over your shoulder.  Live like life is NOT fatal.  Don't wait for it to be 5 years NED.  Let's just say you are in full remission.  That sounds nice :) :).  Declare yourself to yourself that you are cured and then believe it unless your body tries to show you otherwise.  If it does, you'll deal with it.  Eat the cake.  Drink the glass of wine.  You are here now and it sounds like the news is good for you. Lo Rider, may you be well, get into remission and stay there, hon!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 04:51PM Annabella58 wrote: Hi Jen Marie: Hi sweetie, first let me congratulate you on the benign results!!! A big waaaa hooooooooo to you. Second, my daughter is your age and BC has been an issue for her also.........grandma had it (good news is she was a grandma!:) and I have had it twice.  She is very worried about getting mammograms, and when to start that (continual answer, 25) and you will be happy to know that she has been told, as have I, that there is no reason to get them so young, other than for peace of mind...that said.... I would ABSOLUTELY go get genetic testing.  If you have the gene, and even if you don't, going with a "christina applegate" recon is one great way to never have to worry about this ever again.  I have told my daughter that I will be doing that for the non recon girl (and at 52, a boob job is a good thing) and i have encouraged her to get genetic testing.  With your family history, I think a good dr. or breast surgeon will give you a script for it so that insurance can cover this test which is very expensive, a few thousand. A great deal of peace of mind, but even then, if you want to be sure, I would monitor, self examine, and get to know a great breast surgeon as they can evaluate lumps more easily than you ,freaking yourself out in the shower as of course, we all do.  It's way too much stress for a young girl!  Push for that MRI too, as Caya says..it's not scarey, not painful, and my mammo and blood tests and great exams did NOT catch last years 1.5 cm lump which was indeed another bc.  MRIs are a great tool in the arsenal.  This too can be covered by insurance if you carry that gene or are at high risk which with the family history, can help you get covered for that.  (BTW, I don't have the gene.  I was told in genetic counselling that everyone has their own specific case....you could have a strong family history and not have the gene, or a negative family history and have it) I am on the other side of recon, and I must say, that I now have a boob that rivals the original, and bennie, won't ever sag.  So going Bev. Hills, is a definite plus in my book. Your age is on your side as well, but an MRI, an annual mammo and a good surgeon to consult with would be helpful for you, honey, as well as that genetic test.  More good news for you and my daughter........my oncologist informs me that with all the research they hope to have a vaccine for this in ten years!!! I do hope so, that was the best news yet. Have not heard of the primrose oil and vitamin E, you might want another opinion on that one if so.  Another opinion on anything always, is a good idea.  It's your life and your one and only body, you want to take good care of it! Best of luck to you and congrats again on the great news.  xoxo annie

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 10:42PM Annabella58 wrote: Hi there: I'm sorry your family has had to go thru so much ....I am also getting the ovaries out and the uterus also in March.  I don't have the brac, but I have had bc twice so I am opting to take everything out to lessen the risk also...my oncologist and OB/GYN have said they think it's a good idea.  I have been told and also read that you really should not take these things....they are both a form of estrogen, which is what you are trying to avoid, right?  Soy sauce, and flax seed in food (like Barillia pasta stuff) is OK, but not actual sources or supplements of these things.  Also was told to stay away from homeopathic stuff such as black cohosh, etc.  You really do not want to put estrogens (even plant estrogens) back into your body.  They won't help, tho they are healthful things, but not in your case.  If you are overweight, (I am too) that can cause estrogen.  I know we both should lose it, and we will when we aren't terrified, right?  In the meantime, some exercise will really help with your anxiety.  Did your dr. talk personally to the insurance company about your case?  Sometimes they can get things or tests OKd when the insurance says no.  It may be that you have not had cancer yet, in which case, good for you!!!  And I personally would pay the 150.00 or so to get the mammogram myself, if they really won't help you, but I would tend to think if your dr. can show them evidence of family cancers, and will go to bat for you, it might get thru. I know it's easy to say don't stress, but really what will that do for you, besides upset you?  Chances are good that you've eliminated most of your trouble causers (I know mine was definitely estrogen caused) and you could try eating 9 servings of veggies and fruit and do stay away from the two things you mention.  Life is a crap shoot anyway, and it sounds like you are doing a good job of staying healthy!  It's pretty aggressive, but have you considered prophylactic mastecomy?  I think your insurance might go for it and the reconstruct (I have one, it's awesome, truly rivals the original) if your dr. can show evidence of a medical reason why.  It would be one way to absolutely level the playing field. Good luck with everything, I will pray for you to be just fine.  PM me if I can help you out at all. I've been there, and terrified sucks.  be well annie

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 12:15PM Annabella58 wrote: Hi there, just chiming in for a bit of christmas support for all of you. Had 8 1/2 weeks of daily rads with a boost at the end.  I really just went on with my life....please keep in mind that if ladies post on here it is because they are having issues with something in txtmnt.  Those that do not have issues, don't generally post. It was 8 1/2 weeks of non happenings.  Drive to the hospital, put on a johhny gown, lie on a big table, zap, zap like a dentist xray, dress, go buy some coffee, done for the day. I was never fatigues til the very end of the treatments.  I just slept a bit later and slowed down a bit.  I had my hair turn white (it colored itself again, very rare this one happens) and my skin did just fine.  I got a slight sunburn at the very end, but it went away.   No special txtment excep that I have heard good things about aloe vera and aquaphor lotion. Really the easiest part of the entire thing.  Now there are ladies that will jump all over me for this one, but I have to say for me, that was true. Good luck to all of you; I think you will be rather pleasantly surprised how quick and easy it is.  I would get up with my 7th grader, drop her at school, go get rads, go get a nice cup of coffee, on with my day.  No particular quarter given at all, in terms of rest. I think you will do just fine! Happy holidays

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 08:30AM - edited Mar 18, 2011 08:34AM by Annabella58 HI, the onc  is the end person who makes the call, here.  The surgeon will disagree, the PS will disagree, your GP will disagree and so will any doctor you see.  It's incredibly annoying and very common!  They will all need to confirm together what the call is, once they can talk and have an oncotype score to go by. I had invasive, and all my drs. (including my GP) still disagree on everything.  The onc is the penultimate authority regarding cancer .  If you want a surgical opinion, then BS is who you ask.  If you want a cosmetic question and a surgical question answered, then your PS is who to go to.   If you have a supplement issue, then it's your GP.  Going forward, however, do not take any supplements, or do anything without checking with your onc first, as he has now become your top guy.  See if you can talk to someone re: CMF chemo and if it makes sense in your scenario.  See what your oncotype score comes back as, as that will define  your treatment. CMF is very, very doable and you do not lose your hair, either.  It takes 6 months, but it is only once every 3 weeks.  My Onc at first said to get the more aggressive chemo, as "I'd be done faster", but I pointed out that he had no hair, and that my hair was important to me.  He said it was fine, studies have shown no difference in either treatment longterm.  If the cancer types as aggressive, and the oncotype is mid range or higher, they may reccomend chemo.  It's not as bad as you've heard, for many women.  Not your grandmothers' chemo, anymore, with great drugs for SEs. Bottom line, the oncotype will show if you need more aggressive txmnt or not.  I came in at 17, high end of low, so they said CMF was fine.  I could not have rads so I had to do chemo, and mtxmy with recon. Good luck!!!!!!!!!!
